Greek text over 6 lines, becoming more compressed towards the end. The letters are very deeply cut with a bull-nosed chisel, and are painted in red.
rhomboid omega, xsi in the form of zeta with a cross-bar, regular quadrate sigma and epsilon, and frequent use of letters in ligature

Six lines, of which lines 2-6 are indented by one letter compared to line 1, with a consistent left margin. The final line is shorter with the numeral larger and roughly centred. Mommsen suggested that the age formula in lines 5-6 was a later addition, seemingly for its slightly greater irregularity.
Lunate epsilon and sigma, cursive omega, with terminations rather than serifs; use of ligatures. Delta has extended top stroke. Some curvature of longer strokes and arms.

The remains of one line of Greek letters, preceded by a plain cross (which may be a later addition), are preserved on the moulding at the base of the relief.

Slightly irregularly disposed letters, with a hedera between the first two words. In the text preserved by Gualtherus lunate epsilon, sigma and cursive omega are recorded, and interpuncts before the numerals.
Later 2nd century CE or first half of 3rd century CE

l.1 ς
Christian funerary epitaph for Romanos(?) and Agathe
Ferrara records broken bar alpha throughout, as well as lunate epsilon and sigma, minuscule omega, and delta with extended apex.
As Ferrua notes, the formula of purchase is Christian, so to be dated in the fourth to sixth centuries CE.
christian funerary epitaph for romanos(?) and agathe

Seemingly near complete, laid out one word per line filling the available space on an irregularly fragment.
Irregularly incised letters, alpha tending to cursive in form, lunate epislon and sigma.
Ferrua suggests that it is roughly co-eval with the Syracusan epitaph for Euskia, which uses a similar date of death formulation ()

1 Πριγομένια {²⁶Πριμογένια}²⁶ χρησ-
2 [τ]ὰ {²⁶χρηστὴ}²⁶ κὲ ἄμεμπτο<ς > κὲ
3 [πι]στὴ κ̣ [ὲ] ἀμίμη-
4 {μη}τος {²⁶ἀμίμητος}²⁶, ἔζησε ἔτη [— —].
5
Text is set out over six lines within a panel of 26 x 21 cm in the form of a tabula ansata

Lunate omega, sigma and epsilon; alpha, lamda and delta have extended upper strokes; mu appears in two forms on line 2, typical later form with tall upper strokes and at line end a small rounded form mid-line; xsi on line 4 is formed of two horizontals with a detached curved stroke between. The repetition of the deceased's name on line 3 is marked off by a large comma-shaped interpunct.
later 3rd century CE (Ferrua on letter forms)
Photo J.Prag: Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014

1Θάλπων χαῖρε
2χρηστὲ καὶ ἄμεμ-
3πτε · Θάλπο̣ν
4ἐνθάδε κεῖμαι ἑξα-
5ετὴς δὲ θανών
6νήπιος ὠκύμορος
Ash chest for Gaius Matrinius Felicio

Somewhat irregular sized letters, not strictly following the horizontal. Pronounced but simple heavy serifs on deep v-cut letters. Alpha has extended top stroke, with cross-bar sloping down to the left; epsilon is lunate; kappa has short equal length arms; mu has four equal slopint strokes; rho has a large just closed eye; phi has ovoid body with standard height vertical; omega is cursive.
Photo J. Prag, Aut. Assessorato Beni Culturali Regione Siciliana n.10681 del 06/05/2014
